summary.p: The Kantarantāti by Aruṇakirinātar (15th century) is a praise in verse of the god Murukaṉ.
The text appears to be complete (2 Kāppu stanzas + 100 stanzas). The bundle appears to be the fragment of a larger bundle, as indicated by the foliation starting at 29 in U2.
Paratexts: marginal and in-text benedictions, title-page, marginal title, invocation pages, text completion statement, scribal note (U2, f56v).

msItem.title: Kantarantāti
msItem.filiation: Other manuscript testimonies of this text are: BnF Indien 30, U2.
msItem.incipit:
U2, folio 30, recto = incipit: marginal benedictions and title; Kāppu stanza n° 1.
vāraṇat tāṉai yayaṉaiviṇ ṇōrai malaṟkkarattu ‡
vāraṇat tāṉai makattuveṉ ṟōṉmain taṉaittuvaca ‡
vāraṇat tāṉait tuṇainaya tāṉai vayalaruṇai ‡
vāraṇat tāṉait tiṟaikoṇṭa yāṉaiyai vāḻttuvaṉē

U2, folio 30, verso = incipit: commentary on Kāppu stanza n° 1.
Etu vāraṇattāṉai – Ayirāpatattil [i.e. Ayirāvatattil] intiraṉaiyum – Ayaṉaip – piṟamāvaiyum [i.e. piramāvaiyum] – (…)
msItem.explicit:
U2, folio 122, verso = excipit: commentary on stanza n° 100, benedictions, text completion statement.
nalkun – taruvaṉ – tiruvaṭiyē – cīrpātamē-y eṉra-v āṟu 100 tiruccittampalam [i.e. tiruciṟṟampalam]
caravaṇa-pava-murukaṉ pātāravintamē tuṇai kantarāntati – muṟṟum –
ciṟai koṇṭa viṉayākar pātamē tuṇai tiruccentūr murukar pātāravintamē tuṇai murukaṉ ṟuṇai

collation.desc: 1 folio, unfoliated = title-page, by hand n° 1.

84 folios, Tamil foliation 29‒112 = text (mūlam), 6 to 8 lines per page, by hand n° 2. We find successively: invocatory stanzas to Gaṇeśa (f29r‒f29v), 2 Kāppu stanzas (f30r‒f33r), the text proper (f34r‒f122v5), that is, 100 stanzas, and a completion statement with benedictions (tuṇai formulae) (f122v5‒f122v7). Each individual stanza (Kāppu stanzas and 100 stanzas that follow) is immediately followed by an individual commentary (urai). The two Kāppu stanzas are numbered 1 to 2 independently and are codicologically separated from the others (f30r‒f33r; f33v is blank).

supportDesc.condition: Very good state of preservation, in spite of bore holes caused by insects.

additions.desc:
folio 1, recto, unfoliated = title-page: benediction, title.
(f[1]r, c1, 1‒3) veṟṟi-vēl uṟṟa tuṇai
(f[1]r, c2, 1‒2) kantarāntati-y-urai-pāṭam

folio 29, recto = invocation: marginal benediction; invocatory stanzas to Gaṇeśa.
(f30r, lm1) hari Om [the phrase hari O is itself inscribed inside the final m]

folio 29, verso = invocation: invocatory stanza to Gaṇeśa (Sanskrit in Tamil script, with some Grantha letters); benediction (tuṇai formula).
(f29v1) mūṣika-vākaṉa mōtaka-Asta
(f29v2) cāmara-karṉa – viḷampita-cūtti-
(f29v3) ra – vāmaṉa-rūpa – mayēspara-put-
(f29v4) tira vikkiṉa-viṉāyaka pāta nama-
(f29v5) s tu viṉāyakaṉ pātamē tuṇai
The corresponding text with Sanskrit spelling is:
mūṣika-vāhana modaka-hasta
cāmara-karṇa vilambita-sūtra
vāmana-rūpa maheśvara-putra
vighna-vināyaka pāda namas te

folio 30, recto = incipit: marginal benedictions and title.
(f30r, lm1) hari Om naṉṟāka [this phrase is itself inscribed inside a larger Om.]
(f30r, lm2, 1‒3) kantarantāti

folio 56, verso = scribal note: realising that this page was inadvertently left blank, the scribe added a note to his reader to alert him that there is no discontinuity in the text.
(f56v1) yātip picakāyp pōṉatu
(f56v2) Ākaiyāl itil oṉṟun tap-
(f56v3) pitam illai
“It [i.e., the present blank page] occurred [literally “went”] due to memory failure; therefore in this [i.e., the blank page] there is not even a mistake [i.e. a gap in the text].”

encodingDesc.p: Abbreviations. c = column, f = folio, lm = left margin, r = recto, rm = right margin, U = unit (codicological and/or textual), v = verso. GOML = Government Oriental Manuscripts Library, Madras/Chennai. MTL = Madras Tamil Lexicon. TMSSML = Tanjore Maharaja Serfoji Sarasvati Mahal Library.

Transliteration conventions. Unmarked puḷḷi, ō, and ē restored. Conjectural (whether the text is not clearly legible or the character is ambigous, e.g. kāl or length of o and e) readings between parentheses. Alternative readings between parentheses separated by slash. Lost or entirely illegible character: "?". Crossed-out character: "X". Conjectural restoration of lost or entirely illegible between square brackets. Uppercase for initial vowels (in excerpts only). Unquoted text represented by (...). Conjunct letter: e.g. t°, to be read tum or tam. Grantha letters in bold. Symbols/Abbreviations made explicit, between curly brackets: {pcs} = piḷḷaiyār cuḻi, short form; {pcl} = piḷḷaiyār cuḻi, long form, that is, with long horizontal stroke towards right; {varuṣam}, {mācam}, {tēti}; {line-filler}. Unfoliated folio number between square brackets, e.g. "f[1]r". Numerals normalised to decimal notation, e.g. "1121" not "1000 1 100 2 10 1". Hyphen occasionaly used to mark in-word components. Hyphen systematically used at the end of a line when the line-beginning is within a word or within a cīr. Sandhi split to the minimum: overshort u occasionally restored as an apostrophe. Stanzas split by cīr, as far as possible. aṭi boundary marked by "‡".
